Imagine the first time you go fishing.
All you have is a wooden stick, twine, a paper clip as a hook, and bread for groundbait.
Other experienced fishermen have beautiful fishing rods and thumb-thick worms. Everyone is fishing on the same lake.
With time and hard work, you gain experience by catching more and more fish, you get a better stick, and maybe sometimes a fishing line. But after 50 hours you feel like you are still catching only the hurdles and tadpoles. You are not going backwards or going forward.
I have the same feeling when playing DBD.

DBD is grind fest with only 1 gamemode that is unfun for both sides.
BP reward for survival is bullshit.
Most perks are usless.
Most of them you need to buy and grind.
DLC over DLC.
I don't want to be addicted to this game just to be able to play normally after 1000h of farming which boils down to the fact that this game sucks. 

Btw. i hate fishing.

(Written at 300 hours) Generally fun if you like strategic thinking games (in the higher ranks, at least) and a bit of laugh with friends.

Edit: At 1200 hours now, I can confidently say that this game deserves a lot more attention for what it is. It has a really unique style of gameplay, not seen in many other games at all. The developers hit the fanbase with a huge update, a "chapter", including new characters every two months or so. The replayability and variety of this game is amazing, followed by a flourishing community on YouTube and Twitch that provides fresh new content and guides for how to be better and play better like it's a huge race. 

Why I love this game: 
-The game has an INSANE amount of variety in what you can do, what situations you end up in, and the split second decisions you make to help your team/kill the survivors. It is mostly present in the mechanic that we call "perks", which you have four slots for regardless of which side you are playing. They can alter the game in your favor if you use them correctly, and there is a LOT of fun combinations to run with them. In my extra 700 hours or so after writing my previous review, I've never felt that the perks were stagnant in any way, except for ONLY when I use the same ones too much. Every match is different from the last, with different killers/survivors with different items, addons, perks, playstyle, and skill. No match is the same.

-There are different survivors and killers that you can use to your liking. On the survivor side, there isn't much difference between the characters besides their teachable perks (perks unique to them, which you can unlock for other survivors.), their cosmetics/how they look, and how they sound. However, on the killer side, there are 24 (and counting with each update) different killers that each have their own unique powers and addons, and it's really fun to use every one of them and see which ones are more fitting to your playstyle and which are not. Combined with perks, they could make a killer's power much more interesting or effective.

-This game has a lot of room for improvement, you can never "plateau". This game always tests your strategic thinking, your reaction time (not as aggressively as FPS games), and your decision making while under pressure. With 5 generators that survivors need to repair to escape, the killer needs to put pressure and stop the survivors, so no side is free of "not doing your part", unless somehow your teammates as a survivor have a massive skill difference. There's being chased, unhooking, doing a gen, and many more optional actions as a survivor. Each survivor has to do their part to help the overall survival of the team, and the killer has to think about the survivor team's weakpoints, where they can make things crack and fall apart in order to stop them from escaping. 


What I don't like about this game (and how to mostly mitigate it):
-Dead by Daylight gets a bad rep for having toxic or rude people in it, and I myself have had moments were I have gotten angry at the killer or one of my teammates as a survivor. People have the capacity and will be toxic or rude, and in order to not be one of them, It's important to set your expectations correctly as a player of this game and understand your position, because it can get frustrating if you are having a hard time winning on either side and the other side gets cocky or BM (bad manner)'s you. (Ex. clicking flashlight repeatedly, teabagging, hitting a survivor while they are on hook). Playing both sides equally can further strengthen your understanding of how the other side works when opposing them, and reduce "entitlement" when the other side simply outplayed you because you have more understanding of what they did and why they did it, seeing it from their perspective as a killer/survivor. HOWEVER, this game still can be infuriating simply because of the BM'ing from either side, but don't let it ruin your day. The truth is, in the big picture, it's just one match. There are many more to play and have fun in, don't let people make your day worse if you lose, because it's an opportunity to learn.

TL:DR: The game is really unique, fun and replayable because it has a HUGE variety in playstyle, perks, characters, and situations that never leave you in the same shoes as the previous match. As long as you are willing to learn and set your expectations, then you will have a LOT of fun playing this game, especially with friends. There's a lot of new content/guides and a huge community to back it. 9/10.
